column1:
commodity /kəˈmɒdəti/
Examples: A barrel of oil is a common commodity traded worldwide.
People invest in different types of commodities to diversify their portfolios.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: Anything movable (a good) that is bought and sold.

snub /snʌb/
Examples: I hope the people we couldn't invite don't see it as a snub.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A deliberate affront or slight.
column2: A sudden checking of a cable or rope.

column1:
snub /snʌb/
Examples: He snubbed my offer of help.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To slight, ignore or behave coldly toward someone.

impetuous /imˈpɛtʃuəs/
Examples: He made an impetuous decision that he later regretted.
Her anger led her to act with impetuous force against the wall.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Making arbitrary decisions, especially in an impulsive and forceful manner.
column2: Characterized by sudden violence or vehemence.

column1:
succumbed 
Examples: Thai culture as in many other Asian cultures, is succumbing to the influence of westernization.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To yield to an overpowering force or overwhelming desire.
column2: To give up, or give in.

column1:
secularized 
Examples: A church has been secularized over generations.
The educational system is heavily influenced by a long history of Christianity that's now largely secularized.,"Part of Speech: verb

emanates 
Examples: Fragrance emanates from flowers.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To come from a source

flounder /ˈflaʊndɚ/
Examples: He floundered when faced with a difficult decision.
She could not help but flounder as she searched for her glasses on the floor.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A European species of flatfish having dull brown colouring with reddish-brown blotches
column3: Any of various flatfish of the family Pleuronectidae or Bothidae.

column1:
eminently /ˈɛmɪnəntli/
Examples: Everyone supported the nominee because she was eminently qualified.,"Part of Speech: adverb
Definition: In an eminent or prominent manner.

embroiled 
Examples: Avoid him. He will embroil you in his fights.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To draw into a situation

transfixed 
Examples: The sudden gasp from her audience had transfixed everyone. He felt his heartbeat race as he was transfixed by the breathtaking view.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To render motionless, by arousing terror, amazement or awe.
column2: To pierce with a sharp pointed weapon.

column1:
transfixed 
Examples: The sudden gasp from her audience had transfixed everyone. He felt his heartbeat race as he was transfixed by the breathtaking view.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Rendered motionless by completely focused attention, rapt, entranced, mesmerized.

visceral /ˈvɪsəɹəl/
Examples: - His reactions were often visceral rather than reasoned.
- The horror movie was so intense it elicited a strong visceral fear in the audience.

Now answer this USER TOKEN: In what ways can "visceral" be used to describe an emotional response?,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Of or relating to the viscera—internal organs of the body.
column2: Having to do with the response of the body as opposed to the intellect, as in the distinction between feeling and thinking.

column1:
anthropologist /ˌæn.θɹoʊˈpɑl.ə.d͡ʒɪst/
Examples: An anthropologist studied cultural practices around marriage.
Anthropologists contribute significantly to our understanding of human societies and cultures across the globe.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: One who is versed in anthropology.

niche /niːʃ/
Examples: Fashion designers often create unique niches within clothing styles. Niche markets allow businesses to thrive by catering to specific interests and needs.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A cavity, hollow, or recess, generally within the thickness of a wall, for a statue, bust, or other erect ornament. Hence, any similar position, literal or figurative.
column2: A function within an ecological system to which an organism is especially suited.

column1:
niche /niːʃ/
Examples: a niched vase,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To place in a niche.

culminating

Definition: Of a heavenly body, to be at the highest point, reach its greatest altitude.
column2: To reach the (physical) summit, highest point, peak etc.

Definition: To interrupt or cut off.
column2: To repress, keep in or hold back.

column1:
stifled 
Examples: The stifled attempt at reform led to further resentment.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: That has been interrupted, suppressed etc

chastened 
Examples: He was chastened for his poor behavior at school.  
She felt somewhat chastened after her friend pointed out a mistake in her report.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To punish (in order to bring about improvement in behavior, attitude, etc.)

chastened 
Examples: He was chastened for his poor behavior at school.  
She felt somewhat chastened after her friend pointed out a mistake in her report.,"Part of Speech: adjective

provincials 
Examples: Provincials often look down on city dwellers for their sophistication and cosmopolitan attitudes. During the colonial era, provincials resisted the imposition of foreign cultures by holding onto local traditions.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A person belonging to a province
column3: A monastic superior, who, under the general of his order, has the direction of all the religious houses of the same fraternity in a given district, called a province of the order.

column1:
rigorous /ˈɹɪɡəɹəs/
Examples: a rigorous execution of law; a rigorous winter.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Showing, causing, or favoring rigour

rekindled 
Examples: Her love for him seemed rekindled after she found his old letters.
The campfire helped them feel a sense of camaraderie as they shared stories and laughter, reigniting their friendships.,"Part of Speech: verb

column2: To be kindled or ignited again.

maneuvers 
Examples: Joint NATO maneuvers are as much an exercise in diplomacy as in tactics and logistics.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The planned movement of troops, vehicles etc.
column3: (later also) a large training field-exercise of fighting units.

column1:
maneuvers 
Examples: The pilot executed a series of complex maneuvers during the aerial competition. The skilled dancer's routine consisted mostly of intricate ballet maneuvers that left everyone in awe.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To move (something, or oneself) carefully, and often with difficulty, into a certain position.

complacency 
Examples: She showed her complacency towards her failing grades by not studying harder. She remained complacently content with mediocre results despite knowing better.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A feeling of contented self-satisfaction, especially when unaware of upcoming trouble.

tactile /ˈtæktaɪl/
Examples: The texture of these fabrics is best appreciated through touch because they are tactile.
You can learn more about a culture by experiencing its food and observing the way people eat with their hands in certain countries where eating with fingers enhances the sensory experience due to the tactile nature of dining practices.,"Part of Speech: adjective

column2: perceptible to the sense of touch.

oar /ɔː/
Examples: He is a good oar.,"Part of Speech: noun

Definition: A type of lever used to propel a boat, having a flat blade at one end and a handle at the other, and pivoted in a rowlock atop the gunwale, whereby a rower seated in the boat and pulling the handle can pass the blade through the water by repeated strokes against the water's resistance, thus moving the boat .

oar /ɔː/
Examples: Rowing team used their oars vigorously during practice.
They decided not to bring an extra oar for the canoe trip.,"Part of Speech: verb

column2: to travel with, or as if with, oars.

Examples: - The strong winds helped us propel the boat forward. ; Our efforts were able to give enough force to our car for it to be propelled on a steep incline.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To provide an impetus for motion or physical action, to cause to move in a certain direction
column3: To provide an impetus for non-physical change, to make to arrive to a certain situation or result.

bohemian /boʊˈhimi.ən/
Examples: A bohemian living artist found inspiration among graffiti walls. ; A writer's retreat is often chosen for its bohemian atmosphere and tranquility.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: An unconventional or nonconformist artist or writer.

bohemian /boʊˈhimi.ən/
Examples: A bohemian living artist found inspiration among graffiti walls. ; A writer's retreat is often chosen for its bohemian atmosphere and tranquility.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Unconventional, especially in habit or dress.

bleaker 
Examples: A bleak and bare rock.,"Part of Speech: adjective

attestation /ˈæ.tɛs.teɪ.ʃən/
Examples: He presented his attestation for citizenship at the office today. She gave her attestation of fact to support her argument in court.
Attested by several witnesses and experts as authentic without any doubt. The student's performance was highly commendable, leading to an honorable academic attestation.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A thing that serves to bear witness, confirm, or authenticate

obscure /əbˈskjɔː(ɹ)/

The details of his plan were too obscure for anyone else to understand without further clarification.,"Part of Speech: verb

column6: to make less visible, intelligible, legible, glorious, beautiful, or illustrious.
column7: To hide, put out of sight etc.

menial /ˈmiːni.əl/
Examples: He was stuck doing menial tasks at his new job.
She felt unfulfilled because her life consisted only of mundane and menial chores.

## Instruction with Added Complexity (More Difficult)

You are an assistant specialized in the history of language development, particularly focused on English idioms that have origins related to manual labor or agriculture from Old English through Middle English up until Early Modern English. Provide sentences using four different expressions derived from these periods with their modern meanings and historical contexts clearly explained within each sentence's immediate narrative (no JSON). Additionally, ensure your explanations demonstrate the evolution of language by indicating changes in meaning or connotation over time where relevant:
1) Old English term for 'to work hard', now commonly used to indicate relentless effort.
2) Middle English word that means laborious and tedious work, often associated with negative aspects but still seen as industrious; its modern counterpart has lost the strong implication of misery or discomfort.
3) Early Modern English phrase for 'simple tasks', which in today's context might be considered less dignified due to evolving perceptions about all types of work, and explain how societal changes have influenced this shift. 
4) Old Norse-origin term that was adopted into Middle English with a neutral connotation but now often carries negative undertones when applied in modern colloquial speech; discuss the reasons behind these semantic shifts. For each expression used:
a) Provide an original sentence set within its historical context, highlighting how it would have been perceived differently today based on language evolution and cultural changes regarding labor perceptions. 
b) Offer a parallel modern-day equivalent or description that reflects contemporary attitudes toward work without using the listed idiomatic expressions directly:
c) Commentary (1-2 sentences long for each expression): Reflecting upon how societal shifts in respect towards different types of labor and changes to language have altered the connotations, if not the meanings. 
(The response must be provided with clear delineation between Old English/Middle English historical contexts vs Modern descriptions.),"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A servant, especially a domestic servant.
column2: A person who has a subservient nature.

notary 
Examples: Notaries certify legal documents. A person cannot serve as a notary public without passing special examinations.,"Part of Speech: noun

Definition: A lawyer of noncontentious private civil law who drafts, takes, and records legal instruments for private parties, and provides legal advice, but does not appear in court on clients' behalf.
column2: (common law) A notary public, a legal practitioner who prepares, attests to, and certifies documents, witnesses affidavits, and administers oaths.

Definition: (usually derogatory) Someone who believes in or is perceived as believing in rule by an elite group.

elitist 
Examples: An elitist views society from a perspective that privileges certain groups. / Elitism is criticized for fostering division and inequality in the world of arts.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Of or relating to elitism.

contemporary /kənˈtɛm.p(ə).ɹi/
Examples: Cervantes was a contemporary of Shakespeare.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: Someone or something living at the same time, or of roughly the same age as another.
column2: Something existing at the same time.

column1:
contemporary /kənˈtɛm.p(ə).ɹi/
Examples: a modern art piece is a beautiful contemporary work by Picasso.  
her perspective on postmodern literature and her emphasis on the importance of narrative structure brought out some valuable insights in our discussion about contemporary fiction.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: From the same time period, coexistent in time.

institutions /ˌɪnstɪˈtjuːʃənz/
Examples: The local museum is a part of several institutions that enrich our culture.; Several universities are considered prestigious because they have centuries-old traditions.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A custom or practice of a society or community.
column2: An organization similarly long established and respected, particularly one involved with education, public service, or charity work.

column1: Examples: He invested his money into a lucrative business venture.
column2: The opportunity seemed too good not to be lucrative.","Part of Speech: adjective

column1:
patriarchal 
Examples: A society governed by male authority is often described as patriarchal. The ancient Egyptian civilization exhibited many patriarchal traits in its social structure.
In a patriarchal family system, fathers usually hold the primary power positions. Grandfathers can play an influential role within these systems too.,"Part of Speech: adjective

column3: Relating to a system run by males, rather than females.

column1:
fostering 
Examples: Our company fosters an appreciation for the arts.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To nurture or bring up offspring, or to provide similar parental care to an unrelated child.

fostering 
Examples: A long-term foster family is committed to caring for children until they can reunite with their biological parents.  
Children in need often find temporary homes through fostering systems while awaiting permanent placement.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: Raising someone to be an accepted member of the community.

eroded 
Examples: to erode a person's trust,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To wear away by abrasion, corrosion or chemical reaction.
column2: To destroy gradually by an ongoing process.
